title: Friday, 16th February, 2018
bodyHTML:

Soundbuy Didn't realise till this week that the largest fish n' chip shop chain is only 35 units strong........
11:07 am
BE11:08am

I'd suggest that comes with quite a wide margin of error.

pancakes or waffles @grouch fast food chain, known for coffee and doughnuts. Canadian-based
Soundbuy ............that's worldwide..........
BintmeisterGeneral Frontier Developments - FDEV - why the 7% bump this morning?
BE11:08am

Anyway, "An underestimated market opportunity for delivered food" reckons Barclays.

DerivedCategory Morning all
BE11:09am

Growth of food delivery aggregators and logistics providers is facilitating a change in consumer behaviour. People aren’t spending more money on food in total, but they are spending it differently, reallocating their budgets towards delivery. Technological advances should drive down costs, improve the user experience and motivate adoption. And as a result, we believe investors are underestimating the size of the long-term addressable market for the delivered food aggregators. We are positive on the space in general. We also think investors underplay the take-rate opportunity for pure marketplace networks with strong market positions. These factors drive our OW ratings on European names – in order of preference in terms of upside to our PT: Delivery Hero, Just Eat, and Takeaway.com. We initiated on Delivery Hero and Takeaway.com in European Media in separate reports published today, while Just Eat is part of our European Software & IT Services industry. Despite being positive on the opportunity in the US, we are UW GrubHub (U.S. Internet) due to a premium valuation and more elevated competitive risks.

RA That's interesting soundbury, what's the company value?
Soundbuy @RA - didn't check...........
11:10 am
BE11:10am

Have figure one as well.

BE11:10am

rwl Maybe someday people will wake up and stop eating delivered (and processed) food...
Flaneur Cant be long until we just get a TakeAway-Azon which just preps and delivers every conceivable type of fast food under one roof, surely?
Soundbuy @RA - here the link, https://www.fishnchickn.co.uk/
Flaneur We got a tim hortons recently.... to go along with the 78 other coffee shops in our northern market town...
chad_john Flaneur, like Just Eat? ;)
BE11:12am

All of which is ...... fine I guess? And the note discusses all our usual gripes here, about marketplaces being limited to dense urban areas and margins for a large proportion of operators not being robust enough to support the fee creep the consensus seems to expect.

chad_john Oh preps, sorry.
11:12 am
BE11:13am

Barclays says, "yes, but no."

Grouchmonkey @soundbuy isn't Harry Ramsdens bigger?
Soundbuy @Grouch - I'd have thought that too..............but........
BE11:13am

Because of market concentration ......

Soundbuy .on this link too http://www.federationoffishfriers.co.uk/pages/facts-and-figures-603.htm
BE11:14am

Competition is of course dynamic, but ultimately we expect most sub-regions to end up with one strong player. Some markets will be big enough for more than one to make decent money. Acquired customers tend to be sticky in this space. Whilst competition is logically fierce to acquire customers as markets develop, there is a sense of rationalism and, when a regional battle is lost, the entity is often sold or closed down. Network effects mean, at scale, the barriers to entry (or at least success) are high. Dominant regional marketplaces can achieve 50%+ EBITDA margins, like Just Eat in the UK and Takeaway in the Netherlands.

Soundbuy Fish n' chips obviously on the research agenda......
Pseudonym @Soundbuy Harry Ramsden's claims 40 on their site?
RA Id prefer less takeaways near me in South Croydon to be honest
Grouchmonkey Loving the website. Full marks to the federation of fish friers.
RA They're all crap
red @RAneed something to fill the space left by clothing retailers
11:15 am
BE11:16am

The entrance and rapid growth of logistics players, some of which are platforms with deep pockets and a large numbers of users in adjacent markets such as Amazon or Uber, mean this situation is still fluid. As the supply side expands, we think it is necessary for firstgeneration marketplaces (like Grubhub, Just Eat, Delivery Hero and Takeaway) to invest in logistics to keep their consumers engaged and defend their moats in targeted urban areas. That brings some start up costs, but as explored below, we think it expands the market and can be done without diluting absolute profitability (indeed it can enhance it). In general we see Uber as more of a threat to Grubhub in the US than to marketplaces in Europe given Uber has a higher installed base in the US and a bigger driver fleet than in Europe. Grubhub is is more exposed to big cities, where competition is higher, than EU players are. We think the regional networks built up by the European players are, for the most part, strong enough to withstand competition as long as management teams invest sufficiently in technology and logistics. In our view, Uber could be a risk in emerging markets given it is already present in many and they are earlier stage (consumer preferences less formed).

BE11:16am

That kind of thing. But I should probably stop quoting now and tell you to speak to Barclays for the rest.

Flaneur I think I'll call my invention Gloop-azon. Minimally nutritious paste formed into different shapes and salted/spiced to simulate your every whim. KungPo Burgers? Sausage a l'orange? Balti pizza? No problem, sir. We'll mold it up and fire it straight into your fat face with our deliver-o-cannons.... This time next year I'll be....

Recent advertising trends have been better than
expected across the board. We expect 2017 to have ended
on a more positive note in mostTVmarkets based on our
conversations with industry participants, read-across from
recent results and comments from large advertisers. We see
a slightly more positive outlook for 2018 (1H weighted)
helped by easy comps and sports events.

Lefevre Oh great... another driver of low productivity, a small army of food delivery people in every city. Thanks Barclays.

They're buying ITV.

ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 170.40, up 2.4 (+1.43%), High: 171.30, Low: 169.10, Volume: 3.55m
11:22 am
BE11:23am

Buy Mediaset and ITV: Recent datapoints are supportive
of our Conviction List Buy rating on Mediaset (11 % FCF
yield despite improving advertising/audience share
momentum, self-help and Pay TV overhang near resolution)
and Buy rating on ITV (trough multiples of 1 0x 201 9E PE
despite improving advertising/audience share momentum,
M&A potential). Sell Mediaset Espana: While recent ad
trends have been better than expected and Mediaset
Espana should benefit from the broadcast of the football
World Cup, it is our least preferred name owing to a
worsening structural outlook and audience share losses
which no longer justifies a multiple premium, in our view

rwl @Lefevre - agreed - this really sounds depressing
BE11:23am

And in terms of WPP specifically, we have results due March 1.

red @Lefevreits a job lefevre what more do you want? you are supposed to want or aspire to anything these days. thats the gig economy small print.
11:24 am
BE11:24am

we forecast PBT/EPS of £2,090m/118p and consensus is £2,195m/120p. The other global marcoms groups have already reported and the tone has been cautiously optimistic, with IPG particularly upbeat. Both IPG and Omnicom guided to organic revenue growth of 2-3% for 2018. Our WPP PBT/EPS forecast of £2,170m/125p for 2018 assumes organic net sales +1% and margin +20bp. We will update for FX and Trump Tax reforms at the results; assuming FX -4% would reduce our EPS forecast by 7p, though we expect some mitigation from lower tax where a 1pt reduction adds nearly 2p to EPS. After a challenging 2017, we would not be surprised if WPP guided very cautiously at its finals and then raised guidance as it progressed through the year. The group gave a robust defence of its business model at the Q3 results, when it indicated that consultancies and Facebook/Google were not structurally challenging its business, but that 2017 was disappointing due to the major CPG clients reducing spend.

Investors are clearly skeptical and are backing a repeat of 2017 where most agencies’ management teams were too optimistic. Overall, agencies offer a great degree of uncertainty in 2018E and we believe that investors should consider them as momentum stocks. We would wait for mid-March when agencies should know organic for the first two months to assess momentum and whether [Omnicom] should underperform or outperform.

Despite the de-rating, we consider an EV/IC of 1.3x to be rich for business which generates c8%
ROIC and is on track for its sixth, consecutive year of decline. 2018 EPS downside remains,
compounding in 2019 given a c8% uplift assumed by consensus. We return to Underperform.

short-lived.

We conclude that the achievable rate of return in order to reach permanent cost parity may be

11:41 am

Aggreko currently trades on a 2018 EV/IC (exc. goodwill) of c1.3x.
Assuming some improvement in post-tax returns to 9% (vs our 2018e/2019e forecast of c8%) and
a terminal growth rate of 1% implies fair value of c600p, suggesting c20% downside. If instead we
assume returns normalise at current levels with a terminal growth rate of 0%, this implies a fair
value of c500p, or c35% downside.

Segro’s FY results provide further evidence of the sustained
growth in industrial & logistics with impressive NAV growth of
+16.3% which is well ahead of Peel Hunt’s estimated growth
(+6%) and consensus (+9%). This further underlines the strong
investor demand, particularly in the UK where the portfolio
increased in value by +15.8%. Segro’s dividend yield of 3.0% is
lower than its industrial/logistics peers but with the shares now
trading around NAV, we increase our target price to 610p.

CVS differs from other listed vets chains by retaining local branding, doesn't it? So the owners of sick pets don't realise they're dealing with a faceless conglomerate.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

CVS is looking to raise up to £67m through an ABB in order to
fund its pipeline. The company has £40m of acquisitions that are
expected to complete over the next six months, which would
have used up the company’s funding. This looks a sensible move
to ensure the company has sufficient firepower to take advantage
of a rapidly consolidating market. The company has also
announced its H1 results – these are in line with expectations
and we make no changes to our FY profit forecasts. Our EPS
forecast will reduce in line with the dilution, but will rebuild as
acquisitions complete. The issues with the November update are
now firmly in the past, with strong LFL growth continuing.

BE11:52am

We continue to see CVS as a core holding for investors, given
the predictable growth, strong cash generation, high ROCE and material upside
from acquisitions. The main industry peer, VCA Antech, was acquired on 28x to
Dec 2017 and IVC was reported to have been acquired on 19x EV/EBITDA.

Plant Impact has been on our radar screen of industry contacts and we believe was going to be sold to private equity at the beginning of this year until Croda came with a superior offer

BE12:02pm

We expect significant synergies with Croda's existing crop business primarily from manufacturing (Plant Impact currently outsources its manufacturing externally) and commercial overlap.

12:03 pm

And from a Croda angle, still expect a £1 special div at results later this month, Bernstein says.
